awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Emergent Functionalities in 3d/5d Multinary Chalcogenides and Oxides
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract

This research program is focused on understanding and enlarging the class of materials in which atoms from the bottom rows of the periodic table play an important role.  Crystalline compounds containing these elements have an interrelated set of properties including strong coupling between electron motion and spin, unusual magnetic behavior, broader electronic energy bands, and a tendency to pairwise attraction of neighboring atoms. Special attention is given to the exploration of layered materials that include tellurium, as these show a wide variety of structural motifs. First-principles computational methods are used to investigate candidate materials of this class, identifying those that appear most promising as targets for directed synthesis and in-depth experimental study. Comparisons between theory and experiment provide feedback to refocus the theoretical and computational effort. The team provides capabilities in bulk and thin-film materials growth coupled to characterization using optical, scattering, and scanning-probe techniques. The activity provides educational opportunities through the involvement of undergraduates in research, the coordination with outreach programs at the Liberty Science Center in New Jersey, and the organization of topical workshops and conferences.

Technical Abstract

Interest in 5d materials and 3d/5d hybrids has blossomed in recent years in response to scientific advances and applications in the areas of hard magnets, topological insulators, multiferroics, superconductors, and thermoelectrics. These materials are unique for several reasons. First, strong spin-orbit coupling competes with magnetic, crystal-field, many-body Coulomb, and other interactions in such a way as to drive new physical behaviors, such as the effective spin 1/2 state that emerges in certain iridates.  Second, the bonding interactions associated with the larger size of the 5d orbitals promotes inter-cation dimerization in pairwise, chain-like, and other complex orderings.  Third, the relativistic shifts in orbital energies, combined with spin-orbit coupling and bandwidth effects, can drive band inversions leading to topological phases and enhanced Rashba splittings. In 3d/5d hybrid materials, the interplay of these properties with the strong magnetic moments and correlation effects associate with the3d ions provides greater chemical flexibility and functional richness. The goal of the present project is to improve the understanding of how spin-orbit coupling enhances functionality in compounds containing 3d and 5d ions, and clarify how properties depend on control parameters such as spin-orbit strength, d-shell filling, dimensionality, and structural distortions. Specifically, the activity consists of a concerted theoretical and experimental exploration of materials in which 3d and 5d transition-metal sites coexist in multicomponent chalcogenide and oxide crystals and films. The unique physical and chemical properties of these materials provide a platform for a materials discovery paradigm in which first-principles computational methods are used to investigate candidate materials, identifying those that appear most promising as targets for directed synthesis and in-depth experimental study. Target materials systems include under-explored binary 5d tellurides, ternary 3d-5d tellurides and selenides, 3d-5d chalcogenide superlattices, and 3d-5d  hexagonal chain compounds. The research also targets the synthesis of new materials and nanostructures for topological states including quantum anomalous Hall, strong topological insulator, and Weyl semimetal phases.
The methods used in the research are diverse. Comparison between theory and experiment provides feedback to refocus the theoretical and computational effort, which is carried out using first-principles methods including density-functional theory and dynamical mean-field theory.  The team provides capabilities in both bulk and thin-film (molecular beam epitaxy and pulsed-laser deposition) growth, while the understanding and optimization of the unique materials properties is facilitated using X-ray, optical, scanning tunneling, transport, and neutron scattering techniques.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this DMREF project has been on the physics and chemistry of 5d transition-metal compounds, especially in layered chalcogenides, both in the understanding of existing materials and in the search for new materials with improved properties. Such materials are distinguished by strong spin-orbit coupling and a consequent dramatic effect on materials behavior. Comparisons between theory and experiment provided feedback to refocus the theoretical and computational efforts. Our activity has been broad, with 40 papers published since the start of this program.

Einstein?s theory of relativity is usually thought to apply only to objects traveling close to the speed of light. However, some everyday materials have properties that depend crucially on the fact that electrons in some atoms travel at such speeds. These are mostly ?heavy atoms? from the bottom part of the periodic table, including, for example, tungsten, iridium, mercury, antimony, tellurium, lead, and bismuth. In these atoms, electrons close to the nucleus move extremely rapidly, and the interaction of their motion with the radial electric field of the nucleus generates the so-called spin-orbit coupling (SOC). The presence of strong SOC introduces effects that are absent in organic or light-atom inorganic compounds. These include a strong tendency for magnetism to align with a particular crystal axis (magnetocrystalline anisotropy), the use of an electric field to induce magnetism (magnetoelectric effects), and even the realization of new electronic phases of matter (topological insulators and semimetals). Our project has focused on identifying such materials and finding new or modified materials that enhance desirable known properties or that exhibit entirely new properties. Our work has been based on a close collaboration between scientists with expertise in the first-principles computational theory of materials, in the growth of high-quality samples of novel materials, and in advanced characterization via X-ray, neutron, optical, transport, and scanning probe methods. As just two recent examples, we have discovered a tellurium compound, Ni3TeO6, that exhibits unequal absorption of light propagating in the forward and reverse directions in a crystal, a rare effect known as nonreciprocal directional dichroism, and a class of compounds of the form XPS3 (X = Mn, Fe, or Ni) that show dramatic pressure-induced color changes and metal-insulator transitions.

In the course of this work, we made important extensions to the computational abilities of dynamical mean field theory (DMFT), a computational tool that can be used to treat strong correlations in open-d-shell systems while still maintaining the ability of density-functional theory (DFT) to describe band-structure effects in a chemically predictive way. The theory has been tested on several classes of materials head to head with other post-DFT methods, and public repository for these post-DFT methods has been created at NIST (https://jarvis.nist.gov/jarvisbdft/). In addition, DMFT in combination with DFT has been extended to treat strong spin-orbit coupling and optimizing the algorithms so that the calculations still remain efficient and accurate. In addition, the code was extended to predict non-reciprocal dichroism in chiral materials. The resulting software is distributed openly at http://hauleweb.rutgers.edu/downloads. Most of the code developed under this DMREF grant is in the "src/putils" sub-directory, which deals with non-collinear magnetic structures and transformations in the presence of large spin-orbit coupling (~8,000 lines of Python code). Tutorials are available at http://hauleweb.rutgers.edu/tutorials.

Our outreach and education efforts have also been significant. We proposed and organized three major summer workshops on strong spin-orbit coupling in novel materials (Telluride, CO in 2013, 2015, and 2018), two Gordon Conferences (Multiferroics, Biddeford, ME in 2014 and 2D materials inMount Holyoke, 2016), and led the organization of a major materials growth conference (Symposium on Quantum Materials Synthesis, World Trade Center, NY, 2016). We initiated a Focus Topic session on ?Strongly spin-orbit coupled materials? through the Division of Materials Physics, held at each annual March APS Meeting. We also developed focus topics on ?Multiferroics, magnetoelectrics, charge-spin coupling, and ferroelectrics? and ?Emergent properties of bulk complex oxides?. The Rutgers participants have been active in mentoring young science students through the NSF Research Experience of Undergraduates (REU) and the Partners in Science Program of the Liberty Science Center. Musfeldt (Tennessee) is a member of the national user committee for the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory and regularly contributes to proposal and experiment reviews. She is on the proposal review committee for the National Synchrotron Light Source at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Both portions of our team have mentored students and postdocs and guided their career development, with the result that six of the postdocs working on this project obtained junior faculty positions immediately following their DMREF participation. The majority of participating graduate students have gone on to careers at national laboratories including Pacific Northwest National Lab, Los Alamos National Lab, and Brookhaven National Lab. Others have been placed in postdocs that will launch them into strong academic careers.
